text.tspan: 1. In a large mixing bowl, combine the
ground beef, diced onion, breadcrumbs,
beaten egg, minced garlic, Worcestershire
sauce, ketchup, Dijon mustard, salt,
freshly ground black pepper, smoked
paprika, and dried oregano. Mix gently
with your hands or a fork until all
ingredients are evenly distributed.
Be careful not to overmix, as this can
make the patties tough.
2. Divide the mixture into four equal
portions. Shape each portion into a
round ball and then gently flatten it
into a patty, approximately 1/2-inch
thick and 4 inches in diameter. Press
a shallow indentation in the center of
each patty with your thumb to help it
cook evenly and prevent it from
puffing up in the middle.
3. Preheat a grill or a grill pan over
medium-high heat—lightly oil the grates
or pan to prevent sticking.
4. Cook the hamburger patties for
4-5 minutes on one side until they
develop a nice sear and grill marks. Flip
the patties and cook for an additional
3-4 minutes on the other side for
medium doneness or until they reach your
desired level of doneness. The internal
temperature should read 160°F ( 71°C )
for medium.
5. If desired, add a slice of your favorite
cheese on top of each patty during the
last minute of cooking, and cover the grill
or pan with a lid to melt the cheese.
6. Remove the cooked patties from the
grill or pan and let them rest for a few
minutes to allow the juices to redistribute.
7. Assemble your hamburgers by placing each
patty on a bun and adding your favorite
toppings, such as lettuce, tomato, onion,
pickles, and condiments.
8. Serve immediately and enjoy your delicious
and juicy homemade hamburger patties!
9. Mix the patties until just combined.
Be careful not to overmix the patties,
as this can make the patties tough.
10. After flattening the patties, press
a shallow indentation in the center of
each patty with your thumb to help it
cook evenly and prevent it from puffing
up in the middle.
11. The patties are done when the internal
temperature reads 160°F (71°C). for medium.
12. Preheat the grill before adding the patties
to create a nice sear and lock in the juices.
13. Avoid pressing down on the patties with
a spatula while they cook. This can squeeze
out the juices and result in a drier patty.
